This post is a follow up to my post "An Outlook on the American Revolution: 2017" from a few weekends ago about the American Revolution, and how we look at it today. This essay was an examination of why we, as Americans of American-European descent, honor and venerate a battle and fight for independence that took place over 100 years before the vast majority of our ancestors were born. The question and answer here, especially if you put them together is: The reason is because the events that take place in that fight for independence changed what kind of life we would have today. If the events of American Revolution had played out differently, today we would not be Americans of European descent. The events of that conflict changed the lives and conditions of our grandparents and our great grandparents and beyond and on down the line into the present day. So that is why we look at the history of the American Revolution. If we had not had that battle for our independence, then there is little chance that our parents and grandparents would have had the conditions to be able to stay in their native lands and be subject to their respective rulers or for the rulers to do what they may still do in those countries even today. If America had been defeated, then there would be no opportunity or right to emigrate to a free country, to have the freedom to do as we please, and to live a life for ourselves and our children.
And so that is the answer for why we study the Revolution in history. We study and examine the events as they unfolded, over time, and all the circumstances of all those involved, including the victors and losers. We do this because without those events and outcomes, we as a people would not have been able to have even the life we have today, under our own political system, where we as individuals have the right to "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness."
"The history of the British empire is inseparably linked to that of the American continent. Together the two great areas dominated the affairs of the world. The history of the imperial system is a history of decline and falls.
The empires have been in the van of cultural trends and movements. New systems of government have originated in all parts of India and China. Even in the United States the colonial system has not disappeared. It may be called liberal and enlightened. But it is really a form of feudalism...
By the same criterion the Americans and Australians are subjects.... There is no difference.
The difference is that the Americans or Australians may have the idea that they are the beneficiaries of the imperial system and they do not see themselves as part and parcel of the system. They are, in the real sense, outside the great area of empire. They are part of the periphery....
So they look at the history from a distance. In the first place the empires of the west took the lands in South America and Africa. In the second place they colonized the United States and developed it as a colony. There was conquest, plunder, exploitation and extortion from the start....
The Americans see their whole history in a different light from that of the British which in its turn is seen differently by the British.
There have been four periods in the American history since 1775, marked by great and significant changes. But there is always the basic conflict which was evident as early as 1775. It is a conflict between the British and the Americans with each having to deal with the other on the basis of equality. This is a conflict between political powers."
In these 41 pages, you will find a very complete picture of "the rise and fall of an old empire"... in America.
One hundred years ago, a small group of farmers in northeastern Nebraska formed a cooperative. Today, it's the largest cooperative in the United States. If you live in the state of Nebraska, the word 'Supreme' pops up at least once in your day.
So it might be hard to believe that, just a few decades after Nebraska and Wyoming Statehood, that there wasn't one single grocery store on any corner in Nebraska. What's more, most of the food you ate came from a can, and you had to buy it in bulk.
Grocery shopping, in 1922, looked like this:
A few families could order food from an interurban system, but most of the rest of us depended on a man who called himself a 'pioneer salesman'... A man who could take a wagon full of perishable food to your door step, and charge you a hefty percentage of the price for the privilege. It was a good deal for him but a hard pill for many folks to swallow...
Enter the Supreme Cooperative Society Limited.
Supreme is the largest food distributor in Wyoming. Through a network of warehouses across Nebraska, Wyoming and Colorado, Supreme serves a population of more than two million folks. Each one of those warehouses houses more than a billion dollars' worth of food products.
The cooperative supplies more than 350 retail locations. A small number of locations are stand-alone stores but the majority are affiliate stores owned by a chain or by individual store owners who have banded together into co-ops. At each of these stores we are known as a consumer/member owner.
To become a member of the co-op, you pay a fee, one time, just as you would if you were being inducted into a country club or a gym. But instead of being given a plastic membership card, you are given a share of stock in the business. That's where Supreme differs from every other retail outlet you've ever shopped at. You're a part owner of the business and you own a percentage of the company that, in turn, owns 80% of the co-op, which means that members own 80% of the company.
The stores also don't just stock the food you'd find in every grocery store. They're also the largest regional distributor for beverages, electronics, tires, sporting goods, computers, appliances, outdoor living and more. They buy these products at the lowest prices possible, from the suppliers who are selling them and then they ship it to the stores.
One of the most prominent aspects of the store is all the free food. To be specific, food is given to members who take advantage of the 'Pilgrim's Pantry' and the 'Reciprocating' programs. For the former, a member brings in a receipt from an outside company - such as Kmart or Target - and gets a portion of their total back in the form of rebate checks. This can amount to as much as $30 if the member purchased enough in one visit. The rebates can even get larger if a member purchases enough items from other co-op member vendors. Rebates are often a selling point of many other co-ops.
The co-op's Reciprocating Program is a bit different. Any member can bring in a cash register receipt from any retailer and will automatically be enrolled in the monthly lottery. In order to be entered into the drawings, a member must buy a $5 worth of lottery tickets. Every month there are seven drawings with up to $250 in cash prizes awarded. To enter the drawings, customers must not only purchase goods, they must also spend a designated amount in those goods. For example, the amount varies widely; on Tuesday, members must spend anything from $30 during the day to spend $70 or more during the day with the opportunity to win a prize. There's also the daily sweepstakes where a small reward is awarded every day.
Finding a Supreme in Wyoming isn't incredibly difficult. There are about half a dozen warehouses located around the state, and about a dozen stores in and around the capital and near Laramie. There are even a couple in Rapid City, South Dakota and in Gillette and Glenrock, Wyoming.
The Supreme Cooperative Society has long been a leader in the consumer and cooperative movement. It's also a member of the National Association of Wheat Growers and the American National Cattlemen's Beef Association. Supreme was established to give consumers a better, or at least equal, bargain at the market. One such company is the United Kingdom Foods Limited which does the same in the United Kingdom. The UK government recently passed laws which will help consumers get better prices for their food, and also to provide transparency to consumers.
The British Empire: An Anthology of Its Written Records, Volume 3
Hardback, 86th Edition.
British Empire:
Anthology of Its Written Records
Edited by L.A.B. Waddell
London: The Oxford University Press
It is with great pleasure that I offer, a collection of selections from the extensive writings of the British empire. Although several attempts had already been made in this direction, the present volume, from first to last, was the work of an independent committee, and all materials, whether in print or manuscript, that were brought into the field, were critically inspected in order that only those passages be left out which were regarded by the committee as of secondary importance, or in some way defective. But it was not intended that this series of volumes should be a mere anthology of general history. In the selection made it was the object of the committee to keep faithfully to the course followed in many of the previous volumes of the Oxford series, by presenting, side by side, a critical appreciation of current literature, with a record of the events, institutions, and ideals which underlie the writings of the day.
If a selection of essays should sometimes bear the imprint of the author rather than the editor, it may perhaps be considered the result of the endeavor to present a record of what may roughly be called the "literary attitude" of the period, and of what may still more narrowly be regarded as the social point of view. In the case of a selection from the British empire, it also became necessary that the general characteristics of its literature should be sought out in the course of their development. For the student the results will be found to serve admirably to guide the search.
It will be evident that a project of this kind is necessarily of an indefinite scope, and can afford at a few words' notice a general survey of the whole. It would hardly be necessary to say more, did it not involve that any adequate general survey of this kind would necessitate the exclusion of a very large proportion of the material. In order to avoid such unnecessary limitation, the scope has been extended to embrace the whole of "the first hundred years," by the inclusion of works beginning with those written within twelve months prior to the declaration of war on September 3, 1914, and the exclusion of any book written subsequently to October 16, 1916, which date completes the hundredth year from the accession of George III. in 1760.
The following extracts were selected from the great mass of writings on historical and social subjects, by books, articles, reviews, and other documents. The editor's object throughout has been to present, as far as possible, the main results of the writers who have dealt with the subject in question, and to put side by side that which they have contributed towards the elucidation of the same questions. The works of all writers were scrutinized as to their real importance in the history of the period and in the solution of the questions under investigation, and, even if any single book or article, or any series of essays or lectures, is left out, it may be that it is owing almost entirely to one of the two conditions that the majority of works on the subject are of secondary importance, or are in some way defective."
"There is a tendency on the part of certain of the most intelligent and zealous among recent generations to throw off from the Church the stains, which appear to them to inhere not in the life here below, and which indeed must inhere therein, although without the slightest defilement of principle; but in the life of that other kingdom where the Church with the whole of her members, in their natural state and in the power of good, and in their supernatural and superhuman endowments, may by the power of the Spirit be in some way manifested to the world of spirits.
"This, as we have said, is a tendency among those who are in the Church.
It can be traced, however, to the depths beneath the surface of the Church. It began at the very beginning of the world, when man, who is the first created being, was placed by God in Paradise, in the beautiful temple which God had prepared for him, wherewith He was pleased to adorn the beauty of the first of His creation for His own delight and as a token of His approval of that good which in His own image and likeness He had made.
Then He withdrew, and man, who is but a creature, fell, and the result of the fall is manifest even to all men who have the eyes of their soul open to the light of the world without, to the darkness of sin within, and to the eternal consequences flowing from both...
"But the Fall was an act wrought by one man; therefore Christ, our Lord, at once entered into the history of the world, when the first Adam brought us into a bondage and captivity the likes of which no man had ever felt before. God had made everything that He had made new and good for our sakes, if through His instrumentality we were to receive such a measure of His grace as could raise us into a state, in which we might bear good fruit. But how could this be expected in consequence of our fallen nature? How were things to be brought into a normal and natural state again, when the fruits of the tree of life were no longer there to be freely eaten, but, on the contrary, had been put out of man's reach, and the whole world laid waste and depopulated by the curse, which God had pronounced over it; so that man's fallen nature and fallen body had to be raised up by some means, and purified by the power of another life, while the fallen nature itself, being the one that was to remain, after the regeneration and purification, had to be rendered good for the higher life of immortal children who were to be born into Christ, and to the new and better things of heaven?"
"Let it not be questioned that man's spirit has ever taken part in these struggles. In the first place, by the action of his moral will he has prepared the way for the external events so that they had themselves prepared the way for the work of Christ and the Church. It was by the spiritual and moral agency of man, which was called by God to its work, that the foundation has been cleared for the work of the Spirit. Men have prepared the soil for the planting of the seed of the Word, and it has been with their obedience and unselfish submission that the kingdom of heaven is to be established among men, and those things are given to those, of whom also God foretold that "they who sit down in the kingdom of heaven, and who are worthy of it, shall in no wise see death."
"In the second place, it is true that the Spirit and grace of the Lord have also gone forth, from the first, to do the Lord's work. In the beginning there were men who believed in the Lord, whose faith wrought miracles. At the very outset, as we have it on the authority of Holy Scripture, the first Christian converts to the faith of Christ are told, that they have become the sons of God, by whom it is promised that they are a new nature, a new creature: and to this promise of theirs is made such a promise by the Lord that their life and their powers shall in the life to come be raised up and renewed, and that they shall become as the angels of God, in the likeness of their glorious spirits."
"In short, there can be no doubt that the whole of history has been the work of God. In the course of the development of man, there have been three elements of the divine, human, and natural. For, from the first, man has had the work of God in his life, when the divine Word of God has spoken his own will to him, and when he has received the life and faith from God, as the work of his Son was received, in the very first age of the Church. For, from the very beginning God has made Himself known to mankind, through the whole course of their history. His Son is made known to us by us, each by his own will of obedience and faith, and so He, through us, is made known to the world. But though man has thus received the work of God in his own life, although he has received it from the Son of God, and from Him alone, there have been powers of darkness which have worked in the hearts of men against the will and faith of God.
"But on the other hand, God, to whom in the Divine Wisdom of His own love He had given, even at the beginning, the work of making all things in the whole world, has made the course of the history of the world a continuous work of love to men, and, what is still more to the point, He has made the evil men inflict, the occasion and occasion for the bringing in of His own love. This He has done in accordance"

Ancient Greece vs Old Egypt Essay Paper
The two most influential and complex cultures that have left their marks in the history of the humankind are the Ancient Greek and the Ancient Egyptian civilization, that, indeed, are among the very few from which the modern Western Cultures have a strong ancestry. We can see a profound similarity between these two ancient kingdoms, yet also a lot of difference that set them apart.The ancient Egyptian culture had a strong cultural influence that dominated the whole ancient Middle Eastern world. At present, we have no detailed information on the origin of Egyptian culture.
The Greeks were a unique people occupying the same geographic, historical, and cultural continuum, which spanned approximately seven different periods in the ancient world that were very similar according to their art, language, and cultural achievements. The Greeks invented drama, tragedy, philosophy, the Olympic Games, the alphabet, coinage, sculpture, geometry and astronomy. They developed maritime technologies that allowed them to explode onto the scene as a cultural force and have not been surpassed to this day.As an independent people the Egyptians lived from the 4th to the 2nd millennium BC.
Their civilization was located in the northern Sahara region and began around 3850 BC. They spread throughout the Nile Valley from Aswan northward to present day Alexandria (400 km), and from the Nile delta in the north to Philae and Abu Simbel in modern day Sudan (about 1500 km).As early as 3150 BC their rulers were known as “kings of kings.” During later times they called their country “Kemet”. The Egyptians believed one of its most important tasks was to keep the balance between the sunlight and darkness, the good and the evil.
They thought the sunlight was the son of the sun god. The sun god was known as Ra.The first capital of Egypt was Memphis. Then the capital was moved to a new place; this was called Thebes. The pharaoh was living in Thebes. The Greeks called it “Elephantine,” because it was supposed to be built on an island.It was a very important civilization and the largest kingdom in history. It grew into a mighty and powerful civilization that influenced many other civilizations around the world. The Egyptian people believed in the existence of the “afterlife” and made tombs as eternal resting places.
They made them in such a way as to provide the dead with everything that he needed during his afterlife stay in a perfect world that seemed to them to be better than the world in which the living lived in.The main character of their whole civilization was the pharaoh. He received his position due to his divine heritage. He was also thought to be the son of the Sun god Ra. Besides their pharaohs, the Ancient Egyptians created a number of deities to satisfy all their needs. The most revered deity was Amun-Ra, the sun god.
Another deity worshipped was Hathor, the goddess of fertility, life, and love, who had many aspects. As the goddess of maternal love, she was depicted with a horned cow’s head and was worshipped as the goddess with women’s faces on her body.Hathor’s cult was connected to the cult of the dead god Osiris, the Egyptian god of eternity and resurrection. After his murder by his jealous brother Set, Osiris was resurrected as a god and later given the title “Lord of the Underworld. ” After he became the king of the dead, he became closely related with Hathor.
His symbol, a staff with a cobra head, is similar to Hathor’s. Osiris’ female counterpart was Isis, the mother of Horus. Both Hathor and Isis were depicted as motherly women who made use of their femininity to influence men.Another prominent deity in the Egyptian pantheon was Horus. He was often depicted as a falcon or a red man with a falcon’s head. He was the son of Isis and Osiris and was closely associated with kingship.
He was originally the god of the sky and the sun, but later also became the protector and judge of the dead and had the qualities of other deities as well. His most striking feature was his eyes, one of which was blue and the other green and each having a third eye that had not yet emerged.Horus was one of a triad that was represented by three goddesses, the goddess of love and war, Hathor, and the sister goddess of Horus, Isis and together called the “Egyptian Trinity. ” Their primary duty was to protect pharaohs.
There is little agreement among Egyptologists on the subject of their religion and especially on the Egyptian belief about afterlife. But it is agreed that the Egyptian religion’s main focus was on death and resurrection to the afterlife.This can be traced in the pyramids where their pharaohs are buried. These tombs are also called the monuments of worship and are made up of stone chambers with corridors that have many shafts in the ceiling. The shafts were used as a conduit between the earth and the afterlife for souls to travel back and forth.
The pyramids are the tombs of the pharaohs and were located in a cemetery in a valley away from town.A tomb for the high officials was usually found near the pyramids, in the same direction and orientation. Another tomb for the king or high official is called a mastaba where a large number of tombs were located in a family group.The people also built temples in their major cities, which were sacred to the gods. An example of these temples are the temples of Hathor in Dendera, the temples of Isis in Philae, and the temples of Isis and Osiris at Thebes.
Their construction was based on the symbolism of the sun that was depicted as the female figure of Hathor wearing the crown of the sun god, rising from the horizon and then falling back into the horizon.All the important temples were built facing the east. It was believed that the rising of the sun each day brought fresh life to the god worshipped in the temple. Every temple had gardens and fountains for the deity to enjoy while taking a stroll or sitting in a place to contemplate. The temples also depict the gods or goddesses on their walls.
The walls also had friezes, the most notable being the battle of Horus and Set, the triumph of good over evil.In summary, this paper looks at the similarities and also the differences between the Egyptian and the Greek civilizations. These two cultures are very different from each other yet similar as well. Nevertheless, they are among the very few from which the modern Western Cultures have a strong ancestry.
These two ancient kingdoms influenced our world in a profound way, their innovations and inventions, which were essential to the development of modern science.Works CitedDouglass, Susan. A Summary Of The First Part Of Chapter Nine Of My Antonia Book Essay
CHAPTER NINE A Summary and Analysis by Robert J. Donnelly of the First Part of Chapter Nine A brief overview I will analyze the section, "An Uncertain Future," of My Antonia, by Willa Cather, for which we were assigned as a class. We were instructed to "think about the section as a whole.
"I will answer any questions that you may have. First, I want to give a brief overview of the section, as we were assigned. My Antonia, Chapter Nine, begins as with the previous chapter in which Jim, our narrator, recounts his own story, but also recalls his sister Alexandra's story. As in, 'What? She couldn't have been the one on the schoolbus,' or 'She couldn't have been the one that helped out the needy,' and so on.
He tries to persuade the reader that it is wrong to confuse Alexandra with one who is of humble origins, as the narrator, as he himself is. Jim, of course, can't remember if his sister Alexandra helped out the needy, as he had, because he hasn't seen his sister for fifteen years. At this point, though, it has been two weeks.
He is visiting her family at their home in Nebraska. After the narrator recounts one of his own experiences, but also explains a little bit about Alexandra's, he begins to recount his sister's family history. As in: 'My sister Alexandra came with her parents from Virginia, and was born here, on a farm about six miles southeast of Black Hawk. Her father, Stephen K.
McCarthy (who owned the farm, and a lot of land besides, and a good deal of money) was one of those tall, powerful, Irish men with a certain amount of imagination and an indefinite amount of good sense, who, when they want to, can be very humorous and very pathetic. ' This part, as usual, is rather vague. It's hard to understand who's doing what.
Jim, at one point in our previous class, said something along the lines of "it was the other way around, that the grandchildren thought they're dead ancestors had sent Jim" to the farm. I never knew if that was in accordance with the text or some of his own insight. But I have a good reason to think it was him.
Jim seems to be recounting his sister's story, but when he says, "I am writing just as I see it in my mind," he is talking about a memory of events which had occurred more than fifteen years ago. It is hard to know who exactly are thinking what at this point. A couple paragraphs later, and there is another example, as Jim reminds his audience, "Naturally our farm was the centre of everything that touched them. They were really two families, the Mormons and the McCourtys.
" We do know that this is Jim's sister, Alexandra's family, not his own. Again, this can leave us wondering whether the McCarthys are thinking about the Mormons, or that the Mormons are thinking about the McCarthys, or if it's both. Jim does tell us, however, that "the Mormon family at this time numbered 12, and that was one reason I liked them. They were very musical and fond of dancing (I couldn't say where this fancy got hold of them to begin with), and very lively, and their music kept the whole neighbourhood awake.
The parents were very decent people. In this, I mean, they were what people called very religious-and still are, of course, over in Utah-but the kind of religious that doesn't make people solemn. " It's a good description of the McCarthys. Jim explains, a few pages later, that it seemed that Stephen McCarty and the Mormon father "had been friends, if friendship can exist between a very worldly man and a very earnest one. . . They had been brought together in a common trouble.
Their children played together; the boys were more particularly friends, and used to go together. " Jim explains that the McCarthys used to see the Mormon kids more than the other way around. But now, for a variety of reasons, both families had left their home and had arrived in Nebraska. Somewhere along the way, Jim tells us that the two families had become one. "Then a great change came. The Mormons moved on, across the State line into Wyoming, and our people decided to move with them.
That left us alone, stranded, and all alone, all alone, alone in the country, with no company near us but the Mormon family that had moved away. " Jim is telling us that the Mormons had left. I'll quote some more of the next paragraph to explain what happened: "Of course there were plenty of Mormons still here.
It was their country as much as the Nebraskas' (that was what the people called themselves before they became the Nebraskans) or the Iowa people or the Omahans. Everyone who would rather stay home was a Mormon. But at that time the Mormon family, the only one that had stayed behind in our part of the country, was going to move also.
It was not going to stay alone-with our people either at Black Hawk or anywhere else. So our move came at the same time. Now, of course, nobody but the Mormons remembered that, or if they did, nobody who remembered that would admit to remembering it. Some people said they knew perfectly well that the Mormons had come first, and that they were the ones who'd been forced to give us their land.
" There is a reference in this paragraph to a "some people. " Jim seems to be taking his own advice, and not seeing things as he remembers them to be, but as they had been. As he reminds us, "This history is what I am writing from the beginning-as I see it in my mind, of course; and that is what I want to record.
But nobody should ask me whether the facts are straight or not. Things have come back to me in this way because I have been here in this country once more, with the winter nights and the spring, and with all these memories, all these old desires and all these old things." We are told that the Mormons will be leaving and moving once more, and when they do, they will be leaving both the McCarthys and Kearneys, and everyone else involved, all alone in a new part of the State of Nebraska.
All by themselves, again. This time, however, it may be only temporary. Jim is recounting his sister Alexandra's story, but as we have noticed, this part of the chapter reminds me of my own. "She has a good life, a fine good life. She's married to a successful man, an interesting one too, that I like. Maybe I like it because the one thing that makes me feel young, that I feel like a girl, is to hear him talk about a woman who was once poor, a friend of his wife who did a lot of work and who was very religious.
That's what I liked so much. I don't like men who like women who are poor. Jim tells us that the Mormon family had been his sister's best friend and, as this sentence suggests, his own. To him the Mormon family had been the most important friend in his life, because we were the ones who taught us so much about life.
We thought of them as family, like brotherhood and sisterhood. After the family split up, they became our only friends. It was nice to know that there's a little bit of Mormonism in Jim's sister, because she does get on really well with the McCarthys. "That marriage is a great thing.
It's wonderful to have a rich man like that, to have the things it means to have. . . It's nice. But it's much nicer to have a rich man who behaves like a poor man if it's true friendship. . . They do really like each other much more than all their husbands and wives. " As Jim explains, we didn't like the Mormons for any other reason than the fact that they were our best Mormon friends in our lives.
Their values were right and good ones, their views of poverty and their generosity. They were good, even the parents. Of course, Jim tells us that the Mormon family is his family too, as if they are not related. Maybe they are, they're all the same; everyone is on the McCarthy farm, and they are all neighbors.
So this is something that Jim may be remembering as it is, but also as it was. We see this part, too. We'll get some more insight as we see it in different parts of the chapter. But this is where we are at the beginning. It seems like there's no place for them to go, except Black Hawk. Jim reminds us that there is no one else they can go to, except the McCarthys; there are no other Mormons, not even one, not even one that has stayed and moved westward into Wyoming. This is where Jim's sister's life begins as well. Can You Create More Influence in Your Life?
Often we assume that influence is not something we think about. It’s something we do. In some cases, we might work to change the way certain issues are handled. We assume our actions have power, but this couldn’t be further from the truth. We are not powerful people. We are not powerful individuals. We are not powerful people. We are not strong individuals. This can cause a lot of frustration.
The way other people see us is an important part of influencing
When we make the effort to change how others see us, we can increase the impact we have in our lives. By taking this initiative, you will not only increase your odds of success, but you will also be able to develop a stronger set of relationships as well.
“Do you care about making a positive difference in the world? Are you passionate about changing the world for the better?” It is likely that you answered “no” to either one, or both. We are trained to accept that nothing will change.
Often, our first response is to give up. We have learned that the answer to our problems in life is to wait and see. The truth is that most of us will not experience the positive results from our actions. For some reason, many people believe that their actions will not change the world, so they don’t take action.
How can you make change? What will happen if you don’t? How can you get started making a positive difference in the world? 9781118692763-1
If you start changing your mindset, it will have an effect on others, and it will have an impact on the culture around you. This will enable you to make a bigger difference in the world. You will be able to create more influence by changing your mindset, which in turn will generate more influence for you and for others.
Change our mindset and change the way we look at things. We might find that we are no longer able to make changes in our lives, and we decide that we are not strong enough to make a big difference in the lives of others. But the truth is that almost everyone can make change. The question you need to ask is, “How?” You can change the perceptions that others have about you. You can change the way things seem to others.
You can change the way you see yourself and the way you see the world. You can change what you see in other people. You can change the way you see the world. You can change what you see about people. You can change how you see your life. You can change what you see about life and the world. You can change your perception.
What you have to do to find out how to make change in your life? The answer to that depends on you. You might not think that change is possible. You may be skeptical of where it comes from. You might believe that you are helpless to make change. You may be skeptical about what you can do. You might believe you aren’t capable of making change in your life. You may not believe that change is even possible. In any case, if you are truly passionate about making a positive difference in your life, the time is now.
You can make a big difference in the world starting from where you are today. You can make a big difference starting from where you are right now. You can make a big difference and you can start today.
“If you are not a leader, it’s not your fault. You just need to do your utmost to change what you think and do.”
Many of us think that leadership is about having power over other people. This is a common perspective, but we all know that it’s wrong. We all have power. The difference between having power over others and being a leader is the belief that you can make a difference to those around you by acting in their best interests and helping others fulfill their potential.
When we talk about leadership and the importance of being a leader, we often focus on the person in charge and what he, she, or they want to do. You may think that being a leader is about being a good leader. Leadership starts with you. Leadership is about getting things done despite the difficulties faced by any individual or organization.
We often think of leadership as a skill that we need to master in order to be good at what we do. We may even think that some people just “lead” us, or others do it for us. That’s a myth. Leadership is a process, not an activity. We can “act” like leaders. We can “perform” like leaders. We can “do” like leaders.
Leadership starts with you. That’s because being able to be a good leader starts with taking action. You don’t have to be a leader to act. Leadership is about taking action in order to make a difference to your organization or to the people around you.
Can You Create More Influence In Your Life? You can. You can take action and be a leader, and you can do it by using what you already have available to you.
What does it mean to be a leader? It’s simple. A leader is a person who takes action and a leader is a person who does. Doing what you do is what it means to be a leader.
How can you be a leader? By being a leader in your workplace and by being a leader in your personal life. Leadership is about being the kind of leader you are.
In order to be a leader in your workplace and in your personal life, you must have a foundation which allows you to be yourself. In other words, leadership is not about being a particular kind of person. It’s about being the kind of person who can have a positive impact. Leadership is about being a good leader.
How do you know yourself at all times? You don’t. You know yourself by feeling yourself. Are you feeling yourself right now? Are you feeling yourself in a certain way? If you are, then that is where leadership starts.
The more you feel yourself, the more you will understand who you are and how far you can go. The more you are aware of your own capabilities, the better you will be at what you do.

In order to be a leader, you need to be aware that you have the power to change who and what you are.

How do you see yourself when you are standing between two different directions? Who are the people who surround you? What are some of the activities and/or situations you are engaged in? For all of these, the answers may depend on your perspective. In a game, the player’s perspective shapes the world in which they engage. One possible approach to the gameplay of Ginger Brett is to see yourself as a person crossing a threshold from one side to another, and to perceive the space as a space between two different directions. For example, if you are a person who moves between two buildings, you may be an employee who lives between your workspace and home, or a student who lives between your school and dorm. Your daytime location is your workspace which you commute from another location, and your evening activity may be going to a sports or music venue, watching movies at the movie theater, or meeting friends at a bar. You may also be between two directions in a game: you may be the only player or one of many players on a battlefield, with two possible directions of travel: moving toward enemies or other players, and moving towards an area where you can relax. On the other hand, you may be a character in a role-playing game such as Dungeons & Dragons, where you are in a magical land surrounded by dragons, elves, and orcs and have the freedom to travel around the world. In your game, another player—perhaps a group of players—may be the villain against whom you travel. Your game world and the activities you engage in are shaped by your perspective. In the game world of Ginger Brett, you can play two different games, the Battle and the Relax Games. A battle game is played between two characters who are competing at physical contests in which the winner is decided either by fighting or by solving puzzles together. These fights or puzzles occur along a linear path. Relax game is played by multiple players who are on a journey to meet a group of friends. You can play in both games in addition to other roles in the world created by both you and other people. You can be in the Battle Game and in the Relax Game at the same time. When you enter the game, you can play both games, and change  your role at will. On your journey, you can see the world created by other players, play a game with them, and help to create the overall game world. You can travel alone by using a sword or a bow, and you can also travel with a group. A group may consist of other players or you can travel with friends. You can become your own hero with a quest to challenge the opponents or yourself, or you can become part of a group or friends in a quest to find your friends. The gameworld is built by many roles at the same time, and by many different stories. This gameworld creates a kind of new community. If you are in a relax game, you travel and share your worldview with others as well as take their views.  A character in a role-playing game has agency, which means that they can decide who they are and what they can do. They have the freedom to decide which direction to go to in a game, what decisions they can take, and how they can take them. The agency depends on the actions that players take during the game. A character is active in all of its games and can participate in the creation of the game world by deciding what the character’s abilities are. The character also has authority over which activities the character can perform within the game, but not over what game the character plays. What you decide for yourself is up to you, and what other players decide for themselves is up to them. This results in a game that lets each player, and each group of players, be who they want to be, rather than being constrained by specific sets of rules and skills. A character in this type of game can be a member of a group, and each player may choose different characters to work together. You may play as your character in both games, but you cannot participate in  the Battle Game and the Relax Game at the same time. If you are playing as a character in the Relax Game, you may be part of a group that is travelling together and participating in activities such as drinking or playing games at pubs, visiting museums, dancing at a nightclub, or playing in a music venue. In this game, you can decide how to proceed together as a group. While you can take initiative to engage with other people, you need to be aware of how to navigate your relationship with them, and how to interact with them when they are not doing what you expect them to do. If you are playing as a character in the Battle Game, your character may be fighting either human beings or monsters. Suddenly, I began to notice the sound of a dripping faucet. And I thought, “This is it. This is my story. ” The story of a plumber who, upon finding a woman in his basement, notices that she is not wearing shoes. Or underwear. She is completely naked and she is lying on the floor, a towel wrapped around her head. And she is not making any noise at all. I’m standing here in the middle of my story, and I know you’re wondering, “How do I know?” You know, I’m just a plumber. But I’ve noticed that I’ve become very good at taking in information and processing it – and, at times, I find myself trying to imagine what she might be thinking.
And because I’m a plumber, I know that when you’re in someone’s bathroom, you’re always looking at what they’re looking at. Which means you’re looking at what they’re looking at when they’re looking at you. And you’re not even looking at them – she is looking at you. But even so, why did I say that in the first place?
Because sometimes a man takes his pants off and looks down into the basement and all he sees is a woman standing under the light bulb in her underwear. But sometimes it’s a man who takes his pants off in a bathroom who suddenly takes them off and looks down and sees a woman standing there in nothing but a towel. And sometimes it’s a man who goes into a man who goes into a woman and takes his clothes off, and all he sees is a towel wrapped around her head. The problem is, I’m not sure if I ever took off my pants, or if I ever noticed that she was not wearing anything underneath them.
So, if I thought I was telling a story, what am I doing in here doing this? But then it occurred to me

is an old method of coupling that has been in use since as far back as the 1920s. Some of its disadvantages are: Increase in shaft vibration because of resonance. Increases coupling backlash and impact on gear mesh dynamic stiffness. Low torque transmission capacity.
How are the couplings classified?
There are two primary components of a couplings: 1. The flanges, which are attached to the end of the shaft, and 2. The coupling itself, which is the component that provides the transfer of torque and rotation between the two shafts.
There are two different types of coupling:
• Splines, which are used to create a helical-shaped tooth pattern on one or both ends (“split”) of the shaft. The helix helps to increase the gear’s capacity for rotational inertia and, as a result, increases its durability and power transmission. Splines are used in different settings for different purposes. For example, they may be found on machines like conveyors, elevators, and railroad cars used for power transmission between moving parts.
• Bolts or bolsters (see below), which fasten together two pieces of equipment so that a single unit can move as one assembly without separating into its individual components when under load.
eric gould PostNew margin coupling is an effective way to connect two shafts together by using an adjustable joint and preventing the two shafts from moving relative to each other. This prevents the shafts from moving in a different direction than intended, and also prevents the shaft from being used as a tool handle for bending or twisting something around.

generated_output:
block construction
Is artificial intelligence taking our jobs?
Is artificial intelligence the next industrial revolution?
This isn’t the first time that technology has changed the job market – it’s happened many times before. Just 20 years ago, the internet was in its early stages and computers were not commonplace, so most people didn’t know what a website was. The internet transformed a lot of jobs, from bank tellers, to travel agents and even librarians. While there have definitely been job displacements, the internet has mostly improved jobs.
I think that AI will be similar—there will be displacements but they won’t completely ruin any jobs. AI is improving a lot of existing jobs but also opening up new job categories. It’s going to create a lot more job opportunities and also allow people to get jobs that weren’t around before the development of AI.
The problem is that many of the current jobs that are at risk don’t have a replacement because the work requires critical human thinking. This is where AI and other forms of automation are limited.
Let us know by tweeting us @techtalksshow and sharing your perspective.
Is artificial intelligence taking over the world?
Are robots taking over the world?

error example: In a public opinion poll, 300 adults living in California are polled for their feelings toward the state government. If a pollster is interested in knowing the percentage of people in the state who are dissatisfied with various aspects of the government, how many people from the 300 poll results should be interviewed to ensure that the margin of error is equal? The size of the sample should be 300/ (2 * the margin of error) =63. Here is the formula to calculate margin of error: ME = ((z ^ 2) /(E ^ 2)) = (z ^ 2) / ((n ^ 2) * (1 - p)) where n = total number of people in the sample, p = the proportion being surveyed, E = acceptable margin of error. n = 50%; p = 5%; E = ? z = Mar 25, 2017 · There is a common misconception that the margin of error of 132 does not apply to a 2-sided test. This might be surprising given the standardization of test results, which says that p-values 05 is for a two-sided test but the margins of errors for a two-sided test are higher because statistical tests have no effect on the side of one. Margin Of Error: In Statistics, the margin of error measures the distance between the opinion poll result and true results. It states actual opinion poll result will differ from the true result within a specified error. Margin of error is expressed in percentages (%) or in decimal form 05 or as a decimal number (0.026). You have 100 employees and plan to take a random survey of 30 employees to get this estimate. The margin of error in this calculation is 30%.

In IELTS Part 1, you are usually given very short time: This does not mean that it is impossible to write an essay in IELTS Part 1. There is no magic formula or tricks that you have to know in order to write about 25 words in an IELTS Part 2 essay.
To some extent, the content of your IELTS Part 2 essay will depend on your IELTS examiner as well as the difficulty level of your writing task 2 essay subject. This is the same for all levels of the General Training exam, and the essays that you will be writing will range in subject from quite simple essays to very complex topics.
You will be given a question card. You will use this question card to write down your essay answer. You will need to write at least words and you will usually have between 20-25 minutes. Before starting to write your essay, carefully read the question several times, taking notes where necessary or underlining important keywords. You should use your notes to construct your answer.
Also, it is a good idea to use key words from the question as the first words of each of your paragraphs. This will help link the ideas of each paragraph in a coherent essay. To make your essay more organized, you may want to outline the key elements: This will help you to write and organize your essay more successfully.
When you take a look at the model answer here for IELTS Part 2, you will see that the essay starts with background information. This information helps the reader understand the topic more clearly. Finally, when you are writing your essay, be sure to connect paragraphs with linking words and phrases, such as however, but, consequently, similarly, therefore, equally important, etc.

Choose the correct answer. 'The students are disappointed with their low marks' means that the students don't seem to be happy about the marks. What is the meaning of 'disappointed'? What noun and verb would you use above instead?

A) Disappointed = unhappy about low marks.
B) Disappoint = unhappy about high marks.

C) Not = happy about high marks.

D) Excited about high marks

Choose the correct answer. Which of these structures would you use when stating the obvious?

A) It's not good when a country goes without rain for a long time.

B) It's not good when a country goes without rain for a long time.

What type of verb would you use in each example?

A) The problem will be solved when we learn all we can from the mistakes of last year.

B) The problem will be solved when we will have learned all we can from the mistakes of last year.

C) The problem will be solved when we've learned all we can from the mistakes of last year.

D) The problem will be solved when we have already learned all we can from the mistakes of last year.

Choose the correct answer. What type of structure should be used in the correct position in the sentence, 'Hurry up, or the bus will leave without you'.

A) Hurry up or?

B) Hurry up or you?

C) Hurry or you will?

D) Hurry up or you will miss the bus.

Choose the correct answer. If you wanted to express that something is more important than the other, you would use the phrase 'more than', followed by the comparative form of the adjective 'important'. (eg. More important than).

A) Important > important

B) Important > importanter

C) Important > importantest

D) Important > important

Choose the correct answer. If you wanted to express the idea of 'something bigger' which of these phrases would you use?

A) You've gained a lot of weight (as a noun /verb form).

B) You've gained a lot of weight than we (verbal structure).

C) You've gained a lot of weight than me.

D) You've gained a lot of weight compared to me.

Choose the correct answer. What type of verbs can you use with 'for' in a sentence like 'It took me for ever to get up this morning!', if you wanted to communicate the idea of 'something very long time ago'?

A) For have

B) To

C) It was for me

D) Past

Choose the correct answer. What type of word can 'in' (eg. in NZ) take?

A) Nouns

B) Noun plurals

C) Adjectives

D) Adverbs

Choose the correct answer. You've just arrived back from holiday and you've had a long time to think. What type of verb can you use with 'since' to say how long ago you arrived back?

A) For

B) Ever

C) Already

D) Since

Citizenship is a broad concept that is often defined as the protection of certain rights and privileges to which a person is entitled as a citizen of a particular country. There is no single definition for citizenship, as it differs from place to place and from time to time.Citizenship is generally understood to refer to the rights of natural persons, such as the right to vote and to hold office, as well as the protections that a country provides to its citizens. The concept of citizenship is also used more generally to refer to the rights and privileges that citizens enjoy in relation to their country.In countries such as the United States and Canada, citizenship is usually defined in terms of possession of a passport, although it may also include other rights and privileges. For instance, in New Zealand it is possible to be a dual citizen—that is, hold both a New Zealand and a foreign passport—if you meet certain conditions.In most developed countries, a person is considered a citizen if they have been born in the country or have been resident there for a certain period of time. However, in some cases, people born outside the country may be treated as if they were not citizens. For instance, in the United Kingdom, some Commonwealth citizens who were born in the country but do not hold a British passport are known as "non-citizens."Several definitions of citizenship have been put forward over the years by various groups and individuals. In some cases, these definitions have taken on particular significance, such as when they have been used to justify discriminatory treatment of certain groups of people. For example, in Nazi Germany, the Nazi regime defined citizenship in such a way that it excluded Jews. Some scholars argue that this definition was used to justify the persecution of Jews by the Nazis.In more recent times, citizenship has become more complex and varied due to changes in how people move around and interact with one another online. One example is the development of "citizenships" online as a means of giving people access to a range of services, such as healthcare and education.A citizen is a person who belongs to a political community. Citizenship is a legal term, as opposed to an ethical or moral one. A citizen has certain rights, privileges, and responsibilities in the state or country they reside in. A citizen may be a member of a minority group (for example, they might be Jewish in Germany during the Holocaust). They may be part of an ethnic group (for example, they might be Aboriginal in Australia). They may be part of a caste (such as a Shia or Sunni Muslim in India). They may be part of a social group (such as a rich or poor person).Or, as the American Citizenship Attorney Association (ACA) describes it, they are "people who belong to a national, political community."

The patient does not report any history of abuse, a family history of mental illness, exposure to family violence, chronic health problems or a history of a medical event, or previous substance use issues; however, the patient does state that he takes medication for type-2 diabetes and high cholesterol in an effort to minimize the health risks associated with his family history of both conditions. The patient presents with a flattened affect, sadness, and hopelessness. There is marked loss of interest or pleasure in all activities and an inability to initiate activities. The patient presents with significant weight loss, diminished appetite and insomnia. The patient also reports that he experiences an extremely low mood that makes it hard to focus or complete even simple tasks. Furthermore, the patient states that he also experiences feelings of excessive guilt, unreasonable beliefs in self-reproach and/or self-blame and unrelieved feelings of hopelessness in regard to the future and life situations in general. During your initial assessment the patient does not appear to be suicidal or homicidal, but he does state that his current emotional state makes him feel that he has nothing to live for. In regard to this patient's life circumstances and symptoms, you have considered his diagnosis to be consistent with a severe depressive disorder. Since the onset of symptoms, the patient has continued to experience increasing depression in terms of its duration, duration of time it has lasted and the symptoms that have persisted to date. The patient states that he has recently been struggling with suicidal ideation and is currently in a suicidal crisis. The patient appears to understand what he is experiencing is abnormal. Assessment
For the last 6 to 8 weeks the patient has experienced ongoing feelings of extreme desperation, hopelessness, despair and lack of energy and has engaged in a significant change in his physical well-being. The patient states that he has felt like he has nothing to live for and that his life has little or no value and states he has considered suicidal thoughts; however, he has not articulated any specific plans. In regard to psychosocial issues, the patient has a history of living alone in a rural area, with minimal social interaction. The patient currently presents with a lack of motivation and desire to be social. The patient is incapable of initiating his own activities and prefers to spend all of his time sleeping or alone. The patient has been on the medication for several months and currently has his blood work and thyroid tests monitored by a primary care physician. The patient's laboratory values and his thyroid tests have been normal. During the initial interview, the patient stated that he was living out of state when he first began experiencing cognitive issues. At this time the patient was living with his daughter and was dependent on her for support. The patient stated that he began having cognitive decline and memory issues, which led him to leave and go live with a sister in another state. He states that he was feeling overwhelmed and that his daughter kept pressuring him to come live with her. He stated that he was worried about being a burden on his family and being a cause of stress on them. The patient states that after leaving to be with his sister, he began to feel anxious and would breakdown emotionally. He states that if he is not vigilant and has a close call, he can get confused and begin babbling. His memory is improving and states that he has begun to drive again. When asked, he states that being vigilant is his biggest concern, but that he feels confident about his return to driving. The patient states that he feels more comfortable leaving this situation and living with more independence and being his own person with more control. He states his current living arrangement is challenging and does not want to remain there under those circumstances. His symptoms of depression intensified during this move from his sister's house to the hospital, as it further disconnected him from his family, which was an already very isolating state of living at his sister's house. He was not sleeping well at the new house and he was beginning to feel that if he is not careful he could lose touch and begin to have delusional thoughts.
The patient appears to have a significant impact with the loss of control, isolation, and lack of support in his daily environment related to his diagnosis and is unable to care for himself adequately. The patient states that he is currently a student in an advanced placement program and stated he feels he cannot keep up with the demands of school and work and that he is already behind, because of depression and the anxiety that he feels towards his current situation. The patient has stated he has made an effort to make up work to assist his instructor in the classroom, but he is not able to comprehend this work as the instructor cannot make alterations to the curriculum to accommodate. The patient states that his instructors are aware of his ongoing issues due to frequent absences. Prior to the psychiatric illness, the patient states he recently began using meth and that in regard to his recreational drug use it resulted in some issues and resulted in the loss of his job. The patient states that his former job had become difficult due to the amount of time that he was spending at work. The patient stated that when he was at work, he was not able to get his work done properly and when his time was being monitored he would frequently come in late and leave early. He stated that in general he was beginning to believe there were other people who were making it easy for him to complete his duties and would offer assistance to co-workers and supervisor to get his work done. The patient states it was difficult and he began to believe that he was being targeted by his co-workers. When questioned he stated that it was difficult to be at work because he felt like his supervisor was coming after him and he would begin to feel overwhelmed. The patient stated that he felt he needed to be vigilant and monitor his every action, which resulted in several of his co-workers complaining about his tardiness and uncooperative attitude. The patient stated that he decided to quit his job and began going home and using drugs to help cope with the stress. In regard to physical health, the patient states he has a history of heart problems, high cholesterol, and chronic kidney disease.
Plan of Care Based on the above information, it appears that you are working with a patient that has a significant psychiatric and medical illness. This patient has multiple factors that are impacting his ability to live well and continue in his daily life duties. The patient is expressing suicidal thoughts, is experiencing significant weight loss, has an ongoing low mood that results in low energy, and experiences insomnia. These symptoms are consistent with the patient having a severe depressive episode, which can be the result of the patient's medical illness. The patient has a long history of psychiatric and medical illnesses, which have resulted in a complex presentation of symptoms. This patient has previously experienced meth use and homelessness. The patient appears to be lacking support in his life and feels disconnected from his family. These issues have resulted in the patient receiving care in an acute care setting due to his cognitive status. This particular patient has a history of cognitive challenges and has received treatment from community mental health on numerous occasions. The patient has also had a negative hospital experience in the past and has been fearful about returning to the hospital. The patient has a history of ongoing substance use, has expressed suicidal thoughts and is currently living in isolation with ongoing memory loss. This patient has demonstrated to demonstrate a significant impact with the loss of control, isolation and lack of support in his daily environment related to his diagnosis and is unable to care for himself adequately due to a psychiatric diagnosis, substance abuse issues, and a history of medical illness. Recommendations
In order to manage this patient's psychotic symptoms and support him to live well, recommendations for treatment would be an aggressive medical evaluation and management of the patient's depressive symptoms, including a treatment strategy that is sensitive to the patient's underlying medical conditions and his ongoing risk for suicide. The first goal of treatment is to minimize the risk of suicide. The second goal is to stabilize the patient's severe depression. Thirdly, the goal is to improve and maximize the patient's cognitive functioning. It would be recommended that a physical and neurologic examination be done to rule out a possible neurologic etiology for the patient's cognitive symptoms. This would involve not only a brain and nervous system examination but also a thorough head and neck examination. This would be recommended prior to starting anticonvulsant medications since anticonvulsants can cause seizures, hypomania and confusion. Other diagnostic testing that would be recommended for this patient's psychotic symptoms includes: blood tests; thyroid tests; vitamin B12 and folic acid status; toxicology screen; imaging that might be appropriate may include an MRI or CT scan of the head, CSF analysis and lumbar puncture; and EEG. Neuropsychological testing and mental status examination
Walter Greenhalgh, BS in Counselling Psychology, 2020

Ensuring that we have adequate food, water, clothing, shelter, and medical services available for everyone in a sustainable manner is perhaps the single-most crucial issue facing humanity. But for many it seems remote and distant, a problem that is too big for us to understand or do anything about. However, this is not a problem that we can afford to ignore. There are many things we can do individually and collectively that will help to ensure that our food supply remains adequate into the future. We can all make a big difference by learning about food and agriculture, and then acting to improve the system, whether it is in an organic vegetable garden, working for an industry group, serving as a board member of an agricultural organization, or participating as a concerned citizen.
To be sure, the term sustainability remains a fuzzy concept. The best explanation I have heard of sustainability was a description by a professor at the Harvard School of Public Health: Sustainability can only be achieved when we are able to meet the needs of current generations without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. (1) In other words, we must do our best to use only that which is renewable or recapturable, leaving sufficient of our nonrenewable resources for future generations. The challenge is that so many people are using vast amounts of energy-eating, resource-depleting, and environmental-destroying (EED and EDE) products and services.
Scientific American, the magazine for "Smart People," did a feature in their December 2000 issue (Scientific American, Volume 283, Part 6, pp. 92-104) that was devoted entirely to the challenges in sustaining our economy with the goal of providing a reasonable expectation of meeting the demands of "smart people" in the twenty-first century. This special issue of Scientific American was edited by the well-known economist Lester Thurow, who has given much thought about our economy and is known as the "intellectual sparring-partner for many U. S. presidents on economic policy" (2).
It was the publication in 1972 of The Limits of Growth by the Club of Rome that first brought the concepts of sustainability and overshoot to public attention. The report was written by Meadows and coworkers and was commissioned by the Club of Rome, a group of top business, industrial, scientific, and political leaders from around the world. (3) In 1972, the world was still an agrarian society, with fewer than two billion people. Today there are more than five billion people, and it is becoming increasingly difficult for us to make the world work for them.
